reviewText: Charm and vitality that are the mark of Lubitsch films are all in this collection.So much more enjoyable than much of what passes for entertainment today. What can you sayabout a filmmaker who described dancing as " an epidemic of foxtrot". So charming!
Title: N/A

reviewerName: CrazyBird "I am a retired Histology Technicia...
reviewText: This fairy tale like story is told with wonderful scenery, great costumes, an unbeatable score and superb acting.  The actors convey all with facial expressions and body movements.  Funny and uplifting I recommend this to both seasoned silent movie fans and to anyone needing an introduction to silent films.  It is an excellent example of what a silent movie should be..

reviewText: Not a realistic plot, but then what movie has them.  It was well acted and humorous.  Not laugh out loud humor just amusing all through the movie.  Good sense of timing and acting.  I enjoyed it to the end.

reviewText: The Doll is a charming fairy-tale farce for all ages. Just as amusing today as when it was made. Younger children will especially love it. Lovely and still-enjoyable piece of cinematic history.

reviewText: Artfully crafted and restored befitting the creator of such wonderful inovative films. They give a glimpse of the great Berlin film factory in full swing with an abundance of its talented and varied character players.A great rareity well worth watching.Full marks for these rare gems.

reviewText: I watched this because I saw that it was an Ernest Lubitch movie.  I enjoy his talking movies so I wanted to check out this silent movie of his.  I enjoyed it.  It was made 95 years ago and I think it's still very watchable in this day and age.

reviewText: At first I thought The Doll was just going to be a curiosity. The opening looks very juvenile with a cardboard constructed set and dolls that come to life to begin telling the story. It eases into a more traditional film about the nephew of a wealthy man who is unmarried. The wealthy man is dying and he wants his bloodline to continue, so he encourages his nephew to marry. However, the nephew does not want to marry and tries to hide in a monastery. When the uncle offers a large dowry, the monks convince the nephew to pretend to marry a lifelike doll to inherit the money. At the doll-maker's house, the doll which is based on the doll-maker's daughter is broken, so the daughter steps in to cover the mistake. It is a cute and original story which was more entertaining and less childish than I expected it to be.Fans of Ernst Lubitsch will be delighted to see a different kind of story from him. The characters are innocent types and the few references to sex are minor and tame compared to some of his American films. Instead we get a movie for all ages.
Title: N/A
